SystemOutput:
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Mr. Brian is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for congestive heart failure and hypertension, who presents today for follow-up of his chronic problems. The patient reports feeling out of sorts, tired, fatigued, and lightheaded for the past five weeks. He attributes this to the change in seasons and increased physical activity due to home renovations. The patient has experienced some bloating and has had difficulty maintaining a healthy diet due to the construction in his kitchen. He denies fever, chills, and significant shortness of breath. He reports occasional slight chest cramps and a mild cough.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: No fevers, chills. Positive fatigue and lightheadedness.
• Cardiovascular: Positive bloating. Occasional slight chest cramps.
• Respiratory: Mild cough.
• Gastrointestinal: Denies nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Constitutional: Vital signs within normal limits.
• Neck: Jugular venous distention to 8 centimeters.
• Cardiovascular: 3/6 systolic ejection murmur.
• Respiratory: Fine crackles at the bases bilaterally.
• Extremities: 1+ pitting edema in lower extremities.

RESULTS

Chest X-ray: Fluid in lungs.

Echocardiogram (4 months ago): Pumping function reduced at 45%, mitral regurgitation.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Congestive Heart Failure:
   • Medical Reasoning: Retaining fluid, evidenced by physical exam and chest x-ray.
   • Medical Treatment: Increase Lasix to 80 mg once a day. Monitor weight daily and report any weight gain or shortness of breath. Order a new echocardiogram.

2. Hypertension:
   • Medical Reasoning: Blood pressure well-managed at this time.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue lisinopril 20 mg daily. Continue to record blood pressures at home and report any elevated readings via the patient portal.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CC:

Right knee pain.

HPI:

Ms. Thompson is a 43-year-old female who presents today for an evaluation of right knee pain. She states she was changing a light bulb on a ladder yesterday and had a stumble, twisting her knee while trying to catch her fall. She has been applying ice and taking ibuprofen, but it does not seem to help much. She has a history of atrial fibrillation and takes digoxin. She has a past surgical history of a rhinoplasty. She denies any allergies.

EXAM:

Examination of the right knee shows tenderness over the medial portion of the knee, over the medial meniscus area. Pain is elicited with flexion and valgus stressing of the leg. Normal sensation is present. No pain in the calves.

RESULTS:

X-rays of the left knee obtained on today's visit show no fractures or dislocations. There is a small amount of fluid present, but everything else appears to be lined up properly.

IMPRESSION:

Acute medial meniscus sprain or strain of the right knee.

PLAN:

At this point, I discussed the diagnosis and treatment options with the patient. I have recommended we place her into a knee brace and provide crutches for temporary use. She will follow up in 1 week for reevaluation, and if not improved, we will consider an MRI. I will prescribe Motrin 800 mg, to be taken every 6 hours with food, for a two-week supply.

All questions were answered.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Back pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Logan is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for diabetes type 2, hypertension, and osteoarthritis, who presents today with back pain.

The patient states he was helping his daughter with heavy equipment and lifted some boxes too quickly, which were too heavy. This happened on Saturday morning, and he felt a pop in his lower back. He had to lie down for about an hour before the pain was relieved. He reports taking Tylenol, ibuprofen, and using icy heat, which did not provide significant relief. He experienced tingling in his right toes until Sunday afternoon.

Regarding his diabetes, he admits to having a sweet tooth and not having home-cooked meals in weeks. He plans to improve his diet.

Regarding his hypertension, he monitors his blood pressure readings at home during the week but tends to forget on weekends. He is taking his medication.

Regarding his osteoarthritis, it gets aggravated occasionally, but it has been manageable.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Denies weight loss. Denies fever, chills, nausea, or vomiting.
• Musculoskeletal: Endorses back pain. Denies chest pain.
• Neurological: Endorses tingling in right toes, resolved on Sunday afternoon.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Cardiovascular: Grade 2/6 systolic heart murmur, stable.
• Musculoskeletal: Pain to palpation at the lumbar spine. Decreased range of motion with flexion and extension. Negative straight leg raise.

Results:

X-ray lumbar spine, ordered and obtained in the office today, is unremarkable with good bony alignment.

Hemoglobin A1c is elevated at 8.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Logan is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for diabetes type 2, hypertension, and osteoarthritis, who presents today with back pain.

Acute lumbar strain.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient reports feeling a 'pop' and immediate pain while lifting heavy boxes. He has tried Tylenol and ibuprofen without significant relief.
• Additional Testing: None at this time.
• Medical Treatment: Initiate meloxicam 15 mg once daily. Continue icing and avoid strenuous activity.
• Specialist Referrals: Refer to physical therapy for further evaluation and treatment.

Diabetes type 2.
• Medical Reasoning: His recent hemoglobin A1c was 8, indicating suboptimal control.
• Additional Testing: Repeat hemoglobin A1c in 6 months.
• Medical Treatment: Increase metformin to 1000 mg twice daily.

Hypertension.
• Medical Reasoning: Blood pressure readings are running on the high side.
• Additional Testing: None at this time.
• Medical Treatment: Increase lisinopril from 10 mg to 20 mg daily.

Osteoarthritis.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient is managing his osteoarthritis well and does not require further workup at this time.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow-up in 2 weeks.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Annual exam and follow-up of chronic problems.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Ralph is a 62-year-old male with a past medical history significant for depression, hypertension, and prior lobectomy. He presents for his annual exam.

Regarding his depression, he has been taking Prozac and reports no recent incidents. He has been managing and maintaining his depression well.

Regarding his hypertension, he is mostly compliant with his Norvasc medication during the business week but admits to occasionally forgetting on weekends. His blood pressure has been better over the last several years.

The patient had a lobectomy a couple of years ago. He reports no significant issues with shortness of breath, except during high heat and pollen season.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Ears, Nose, Mouth, and Throat: Endorses nasal congestion from pollen.
• Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain, endorses occasional chest pounding during exercise.
• Respiratory: Endorses shortness of breath with exertion.
• Psychiatric: Endorses depression.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Neurological/Psychological: Appropriate mood and affect.
• Respiratory: Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
• Cardiovascular: Slight 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.
• Musculoskeletal: No lower extremity edema.

VITALS REVIEWED

• Blood Pressure: 120/80 mmHg.

RESULTS

EKG: Normal.
Chest X-ray: Normal, no concerns related to prior lobectomy.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Depression:
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient is doing well on Prozac 20 mg daily.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue current medication.
   • Patient Education and Counseling: Refill Prozac prescription.

2. Hypertension:
   • Medical Reasoning: Blood pressure is controlled, but patient admits to occasional non-compliance on weekends.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue current medication (Norvasc).
   • Additional Testing: Order an echocardiogram for the murmur.

3. Prior Lobectomy:
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient is exercising regularly and has no significant respiratory issues.
   • Medical Treatment: No further follow-up with the surgeon is needed.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CC:

Right index finger pain.

HPI:

Ms. Brooks is a 48-year-old female who presents today for an evaluation of right index finger pain after a skiing accident over the weekend. She reports that her finger was bent back while skiing over moguls.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS:

Miralax

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:

Constipation
Appendectomy at age 18

EXAM:

Examination of the right index finger shows tenderness over the distal phalanx. No tenderness over the proximal joint or metacarpophalangeal joint. Pain with flexion.

RESULTS:

X-rays of the right index finger obtained on today's visit show no fractures and normal alignment.

IMPRESSION:

Right index finger contusion.

PLAN:

At this point, I discussed the diagnosis and treatment options with the patient. I recommend an aluminum foam splint and a prescription for Motrin 600 mg every 6 hours for one week. The patient is advised to call and return if the pain does not improve within a week. All questions were answered.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Iron deficiency anemia.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Ms. Christina Cooper is a 65-year-old female with a long-standing history of iron deficiency anemia, who presents today for further evaluation. She was recently unable to donate blood due to her anemia. The patient reports fatigue, feverishness with chills, shortness of breath, wheezing, and headaches. She also experiences cold intolerance and worsening anxiety and depression. She has been anemic since the age of 13 and had a hysterectomy in 1996. Her last colonoscopy was approximately 5-6 years ago with no significant findings.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Endorses fatigue, feverishness, and chills.
• Respiratory: Endorses shortness of breath and wheezing.
• Neurological: Endorses headaches.
• Psychiatric: Endorses worsening anxiety and depression.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• General: Patient is alert and oriented.
• Cardiovascular: Normal heart sounds.
• Respiratory: Clear lung fields.
• Abdomen: Soft, non-tender, and non-distended.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Ms. Christina Cooper is a 65-year-old female with a long-standing history of iron deficiency anemia, who presents today for further evaluation.

Iron deficiency anemia.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient has been dealing with anemia since the age of 13, and her recent blood work revealed low hemoglobin, stable hematocrit, normal iron labs, and low ferritin. She is currently taking ferrous sulfate 25 mg twice daily and over-the-counter vitamin B12.
• Additional Testing: We will schedule an upper endoscopy and colonoscopy to assess for potential sources of anemia or GI bleed. If these tests are inconclusive, a capsule endoscopy will be considered. We will recheck CBC, iron, ferritin, B12, and folate in 12 weeks.
• Specialist Referrals: We will refer her to a hematologist for further evaluation and management.
• Patient Education and Counseling: The patient should continue taking her iron pills with orange juice to improve iron absorption. She will follow up with us for any questions or worsening symptoms.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Worsening headaches and incidental pituitary lesion.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Mr. Bruce Ward is a 52-year-old male who presents to the clinic for consultation regarding a newly diagnosed pituitary lesion. He initially presented to his primary care provider, Dr. Henry Howard, on 3/1/21 with complaints of worsening headaches over the past few months. The patient denies any history of headaches. His past clinical history is unremarkable.

Workup for worsening headaches was initiated with brain MRI and serology, where the pituitary lesion was incidentally discovered. Labs dated 3/3/21, including CBC, UNES, UH, coagulation, and CRP, were all normal. Pituitary hormone profile demonstrates a low TSH, with all other results being normal. MRI of the brain with contrast from 3/4/21 reveals a pituitary lesion with elevation and compression of the optic chiasm. The ventricles are normal in size, and no other abnormalities are noted.

The patient describes the headaches as a dull, nagging ache located behind his eyes. The onset was gradual, starting about three months ago, and has worsened over time. The headaches are worse in the morning and last a few hours at a time. The patient denies any other symptoms, such as feeling sick, fever, rashes, neck stiffness, numbness, weakness, or passing out. However, he has noticed recently bumping into door frames.

PAST HISTORY

Unremarkable.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Computer programmer, married for 25 years, recently bought a small house. No history of alcohol, smoking, or recreational drug use.

FAMILY HISTORY

Adopted, unknown family history.

EXAMINATION

The patient is alert, oriented to time, place, and person. Affect is appropriate and speech is fluent. Cranial nerve examination is grossly intact. No focal motor or sensory deficit in the upper or lower extremities. Visual acuity and eye movements are normal. Pupils are equal and reactive. Visual field testing reveals bitemporal hemianopia. Color vision is normal.

ASSESSMENT

Pituitary adenoma with optic chiasmal compression.

PLAN

1. Refer the patient to an eye doctor for a full exam and visual field test to map peripheral vision prior to surgery.
2. Schedule transsphenoidal surgery to excise and decompress the pituitary fossa.
3. Monitor post-surgery for improvement in vision and resolution of headaches.
4. Send removed adenoma to pathology for diagnosis confirmation.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Betty Hill, a 52-year-old female with a past medical history of uterine fibroids, anemia, and gallbladder removal, presents with a referral from the ER for esophagitis. The patient experienced chest pain for four days in early October 2020, which resolved on its own. She has not had any chest pain since then. The pain was located in the center of her chest, behind the breastbone, and was sharp in nature. The patient reported difficulty swallowing during the episode, which has also resolved. The pain was worse with eating. She denies any recent abdominal pain and reports normal bowel movements. The patient has been trying to lose weight and was going through a stressful job transition at the time of the chest pain episode.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

Abdomen
• Examination of Abdomen: Mild tenderness to light palpation in the upper abdominal quadrants. No pain or tenderness in the lower abdomen.

RESULTS

ER visit: EKG and blood tests were normal.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

The patient is a 52-year-old female who presents with a referral for esophagitis following an episode of chest pain and difficulty swallowing in October 2020. The chest pain and swallowing issues have resolved, and the patient has been asymptomatic for three months. Possible etiologies include GERD, dyspepsia, esophagitis, musculoskeletal etiologies, and anxiety. The patient's job transition stress may have contributed to an anxiety attack, with or without a contribution from musculoskeletal etiologies.

The patient was offered the option of an EGD or upper endoscopy to evaluate her esophagus and stomach, but given the resolution of her symptoms and the time elapsed since the episode, she elected to self-monitor her symptoms and call with any reoccurrence or change. The patient will follow up as needed for any other GI complaints.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Evaluation of kidneys due to Smith-Magenis Syndrome.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Katherine is a 22-month-old female with a history of Smith-Magenis Syndrome, who presents today for evaluation of her kidneys. The patient's mother reports that Katherine has been doing well overall, but has had some issues with feeding and reflux. She is currently in feeding therapy, occupational therapy, and physical therapy. Speech therapy is scheduled to begin in the next couple of weeks. Katherine has seen multiple specialists, including a geneticist, who mentioned that individuals with Smith-Magenis Syndrome may have kidney anomalies.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: No fever, chills, or weight loss.
• Gastrointestinal: History of reflux and feeding difficulties.
• Genitourinary: 8-10 wet diapers per day.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• General: Well-nourished female, slightly fussy when examined.
• Eyes: Small appearing.
• Musculoskeletal: Mild hypotonia of the lower extremities and arms.
• Genitourinary: Normal external female genitalia.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Katherine is a 22-month-old female with a history of Smith-Magenis Syndrome, presenting for evaluation of her kidneys due to the potential for congenital anomalies associated with her condition.

• Medical Reasoning: Congenital anomalies of the kidney and urinary tract have been reported in the literature for individuals with Smith-Magenis Syndrome. The patient is currently having a normal number of wet diapers per day, but further evaluation is warranted to ensure proper kidney function.
• Additional Testing: We will obtain a kidney ultrasound today to screen for any abnormalities.
• Follow-up: If there are abnormalities on the kidney ultrasound, we will determine next steps and future follow-up. The family lives in Dallas, Georgia, so her follow-up should be at the town center location. If the ultrasound is normal, no further follow-up with nephrology will be needed.

Patient Agreements: The patient's mother understands and agrees with the recommended medical evaluation plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right wrist pain and swelling.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Diana is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of right wrist pain and swelling. The onset of her pain began when she slipped on the stairs while doing laundry and tried to catch herself with her arms outstretched. The patient reports severe pain in her right wrist, rating it as a 9 out of 10. She has been icing her wrist, using an ace wrap, and taking ibuprofen, which provided minimal relief. The patient denies any previous injuries to this arm.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Positive right wrist pain and swelling.
Neurological: Mild tingling in fingers, no numbness.

VITALS

BP: 140/70
HR: 80 bpm
RR: 20 bpm
Temp: 97.2°F
SPO2: Not reported.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Head/Neck: No adenopathy, thyromegaly, or carotid bruit.
CV: No murmur, rub, or gallop.
Pulmonary: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally.
Extremities: Palpable pulses, no lower edema.
Upper extremities: Normal range of movement except for the right wrist.
Right wrist: Pain on flexion, extension, radial deviation, and ulnar deviation. Limited ability to make a fist. Swelling, ecchymosis, and tenderness on palpation. Bony crepitus present.

RESULTS

X-ray of the right wrist reveals a Colles' fracture.

ASSESSMENT

Colles' fracture of the right wrist.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I have had a lengthy discussion with the patient in regards to her current symptoms. I have explained to her that her symptoms are consistent with a Colles' fracture. I have recommended conservative treatment initially with a brace. The patient will be scheduled for surgery as soon as possible. Post-surgery, the patient will be placed in a brace for six weeks and will attend physical therapy three times per week. The patient will be prescribed 50 mg of Ultram every six hours for pain management. A follow-up appointment will be scheduled in one month to assess the patient's progress and discuss her upcoming vacation plans.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient is advised to contact the office if her pain does not improve or worsens.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right knee pain.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Hypertension.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient reports working on his property when the injury occurred.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Denies fever.
Musculoskeletal: Reports right knee pain and swelling.

VITALS

Blood pressure: 150/70 mmHg
Heart rate: Not provided
Respiration: Not provided
No fever.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Respiratory
- Assessment of Respiratory Effort: Normal respiratory effort. Lungs clear bilaterally.

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.

Musculoskeletal
- Right knee: Pain with flexion and extension. Pain to palpation of the medial aspect. Edema and effusion present.

RESULTS

X-rays of the right knee were obtained and reviewed. No fractures or bony abnormalities were found.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Right knee MCL strain.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient reports slipping and falling, causing knee pain and swelling.
- Medical Treatment: Prescribe ibuprofen 800 mg twice daily for pain and swelling. Provide a knee brace for support. Recommend icing the knee for 20 minutes, 3-4 times daily.
- Patient Education and Counseling: Advise the patient to elevate and rest the leg, and avoid putting pressure on the knee.

2. Hypertension.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient has a history of hypertension and is currently on 20 mg of lisinopril. Blood pressure was elevated at 150/70 mmHg during the visit.
- Medical Treatment: Continue with 20 mg of lisinopril. Refer the patient to a nutritionist for dietary counseling to help manage hypertension.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up as needed.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left shoulder pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Wayne is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of left shoulder pain. The onset of his pain began 3 weeks ago, without any improvement. He denies any specific injury; however, he has been renovating his basement and suspects it might be related. The patient states he is very active and has experienced occasional aches and pains that usually resolve with Tylenol.

The patient reports significant pain with reaching, lifting, and overhead activities. The pain is constant and worsens when pressure is applied, such as when lying on the affected shoulder. He states the pain is primarily located in the left shoulder and denies it radiates down into the left arm. The patient also reports difficulty sleeping secondary to the pain. He denies any numbness or tingling in his left arm or fingers. He has been taking Tylenol for pain, which provides partial relief.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports left shoulder pain. Neurological: Denies numbness or tingling.

VITALS

All vital signs are within the normal limits.

PHYSICAL EXAM

MSK: Examination of the left shoulder: Limited active and passive ROM. Tenderness over the greater tuberosity of the humerus. No tenderness at the sternoclavicular or AC joints. Good hand grip. Neurovascularly intact distally. Capillary refill is less than 3 seconds. Sensation is intact to light touch distally.

RESULTS

X-rays of the left shoulder were obtained and reviewed today. These are normal and reveal no fracture or bony abnormalities.

ASSESSMENT

Left shoulder pain, likely rotator cuff tendinopathy.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I have had a lengthy discussion with him regarding his current symptoms. I have explained that his x-rays did not reveal any signs of a fracture. I have recommended that we obtain an MRI of the left shoulder to evaluate for possible rotator cuff tendinopathy. The patient was provided with a referral to formal physical therapy. He will engage in a 6-to-8-week course in order to strengthen his left shoulder. I have also advised him to take Tylenol as needed for pain. If his symptoms do not improve, we may consider a steroid injection to the left shoulder.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up with me once the MRI results are available for review and further discussion.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left knee pain and instability.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Andrea is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of left knee pain and instability. The patient reports that her left knee occasionally gives out while walking, causing her to feel like she is going to fall. This occurs less than once a day and resolves quickly. She denies any history of injury to the left knee and has not taken any medications for pain. The patient is concerned about her upcoming trip, which will involve a lot of walking and line dancing, and is unsure if she will be able to participate due to her knee issues.

MEDICATIONS

The patient is currently taking Farxiga, Amlodipine, Lisinopril, Hydrochlorothiazide, and Metformin.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports left knee pain and instability. Denies right knee pain.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Vital signs: Temperature 98.2, Pulse 72, Respirations 16, Blood Pressure 122/70.

Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, 2/6 systolic ejection murmur at left base.

Respiratory: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally.

MSK: Examination of the left knee: No ecchymosis, edema, or effusion. No pain to palpation. Full range of motion. Negative varus and valgus test.

RESULTS

Left knee x-ray: No evidence of fracture or bony abnormality.

ASSESSMENT

1. Left knee pain and instability, likely due to arthritis.
2. Hypertension.
3. Diabetes mellitus.

PLAN

1. For the left knee pain and instability, prescribe meloxicam 15 mg daily and consider initiating physical therapy to strengthen the surrounding muscles.
2. Continue Lisinopril 20 mg daily for hypertension and order an echocardiogram to evaluate the heart murmur.
3. Order a hemoglobin A1c test and lipid panel for diabetes management and potential adjustment of Metformin dosage.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Cough and sore throat.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient is a 53-year-old female with a recent diagnosis of stage three non-small cell lung cancer, currently undergoing neo-adjuvant chemotherapy. She has a 4.4 cm left upper lobe nodule, biopsy positive for adenocarcinoma. Molecular testing is pending.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient reports good support from family, friends, and nursing staff.

MEDICATIONS

Patient is currently on cisplatin and etoposide chemotherapy.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Reports fatigue.
Respiratory: Reports a dry cough and sore throat.
Gastrointestinal: Denies difficulty swallowing or feeling of food getting stuck.

VITALS

Oxygen saturation: Within normal limits.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Head and Neck
- Examination: No cervical lymphadenopathy or supraclavicular adenopathy.

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs.

Respiratory
- Auscultation of Lungs: Crackles bilaterally.

Skin
- Examination: Erythema on the anterior side of the chest on the left side, possibly related to radiation.

Lower Extremities
- Examination: No edema.

RESULTS

Chest X-ray: Mild radiation pneumonitis.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Lung cancer.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient is currently undergoing chemotherapy with cisplatin and etoposide, as well as radiation therapy.
- Medical Treatment: Continue current chemotherapy regimen and radiation dose. Repeat imaging after completion of radiation therapy to assess tumor size for potential surgical removal.

2. Radiation pneumonitis.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient's cough and crackles on lung exam are likely due to mild radiation pneumonitis.
- Medical Treatment: Prescribe low-dose prednisone (40 mg daily for 5 days) to reduce inflammation.

3. Sore throat and painful swallowing.
- Medical Reasoning: Inflammation in the esophagus may be contributing to the patient's sore throat and painful swallowing.
- Medical Treatment: In addition to prednisone, prescribe lidocaine swish and swallow to be used four times a day to help with swallowing and prevent dehydration and further weight loss.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Low Immunoglobulin A level.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Patient reports frequent colds in the wintertime that tend to linger for a long time. No recent history of abdominal infections or diarrhea. Patient was recently diagnosed with type 2 diabetes and started on metformin.

FAMILY HISTORY

No known family history of immune deficiencies.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient works at a family-owned donut shop.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: No fever.
Respiratory: No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
Gastrointestinal: No abdominal tenderness.

VITALS

All vitals within normal limits.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs.
Respiratory: Lungs clear.
Neck: No lymphadenopathy.
Abdominal: Soft, non-tender.

LABORATORY RESULTS

Low Immunoglobulin A level.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Low Immunoglobulin A level.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient's lab work is consistent with an IgA deficiency. However, patient does not seem to have frequent infections or complications related to the deficiency.
- Additional Testing: Order blood work to check for other immunodeficiencies.
- Patient Education and Counseling: Discussed the nature of IgA deficiency and advised the patient to watch for infections that do not resolve or any changes in their abdominal tract. Instructed the patient to inform healthcare providers of their IgA deficiency if they ever need blood products.

2. Type 2 Diabetes.
- Continue management with metformin and monitor blood glucose levels.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right elbow pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Lawrence is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of right elbow pain. The patient has been experiencing right elbow pain for approximately 4 days. He reports that the pain is localized to the inside of his elbow and can radiate down into his forearm. He denies any trauma or previous injury to the elbow. The patient has been engaging in pottery activities recently, which he believes may have contributed to the pain. He has tried ibuprofen for pain relief with minimal success.

SOCIAL HISTORY

The patient has been engaging in pottery activities during the pandemic.

MEDICATIONS

The patient reports that he has been taking ibuprofen for pain relief.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports right elbow pain.

PHYSICAL EXAM

CV: Pulses are equal in all extremities.
NEURO: Sensation is normal to light touch distally.
MSK: 
Examination of the right elbow: Pain to palpation along the medial aspect. No pain with supination. Pain with pronation. Pain with resistance against flexion of the left wrist.

RESULTS

X-ray images of the right elbow were obtained and reviewed in the office today. These reveal no evidence of fracture or bony abnormality.

ASSESSMENT

Medial epicondylitis.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, we discussed the current symptoms and management plan. The patient is advised to rest the elbow, wear a sling while awake, apply ice to the elbow for 20 minutes three times a day, and take ibuprofen 600 mg q.6 h. with food for a full week. The patient is also advised to avoid pottery activities for the next couple of weeks. A follow-up appointment is scheduled for one week to evaluate progress.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Emergency department follow up after a fall and chest pain.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient reports history of hypertension and recent dietary indiscretion.

MEDICATIONS

Patient reports taking Bumex 2 mg once daily, Cozaar 100 mg daily, and Norvasc 5 mg once daily, but admits to occasional missed doses.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Denies sleep disturbance.
Cardiovascular: Reports occasional chest pain, thought to be heartburn.
Respiratory: Reports shortness of breath during exertion.
Genitourinary: No complaints.

VITALS

Blood Pressure: 128/72 mmHg
Temperature: 98.7 degrees F
Heart Rate: 72 bpm
Oxygen Saturation: 96%

PHYSICAL EXAM

Neck
- General Examination: No jugular venous distention.

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Stable 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.

Respiratory
- Lung Examination: Clear bilaterally.

Musculoskeletal
- Examination: Trace lower extremity edema.

RESULTS

Echocardiogram reveals a preserved ejection fraction of 55%, abnormal diastolic filling, and mild-to-moderate mitral regurgitation.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Congestive heart failure.
- Medical Reasoning: Likely caused by dietary indiscretion and uncontrolled hypertension.
- Patient Education and Counseling: Encouraged the patient to continue making dietary modifications, including limiting sodium intake. Advised to monitor weight daily and contact the doctor if a gain of 3 pounds in 2 days occurs.
- Medical Treatment: Continue with Bumex 2 mg once daily. Referral placed for consult with a nutritionist for education and recommendations regarding diet.

2. Hypertension.
- Medical Reasoning: Poorly controlled due to inconsistent compliance with medication and dietary indiscretion.
- Patient Education and Counseling: Discussed dietary modifications.
- Medical Treatment: Continue on Cozaar 100 mg daily and Norvasc 5 mg once daily. Renal artery ultrasound ordered to rule out any issues such as renal artery stenosis.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up in 3 months.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right-sided abdominal pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Russell is a patient who presents with sharp pain on the right side of his abdomen below his ribs for the last several days. The pain radiates to his lower abdomen and groin. The pain is intermittent and comes in waves. He reports burning sensation during urination and darker urine. He has taken Tylenol for pain relief, but it has not been effective. He feels nauseated but has not vomited. The patient has a history of kidney stones and a family history of kidney stones (father).

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Gastrointestinal: Reports nausea and burning sensation during urination.

VITALS

Not provided.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Abdomen: No tenderness to palpation, no rebound or guarding, no peritoneal signs. Positive CVA tenderness on the right flank.

RESULTS

The CT scan of the abdomen revealed a 0.5 cm stone located in the proximal right ureter. There is no evidence of hydronephrosis.

ASSESSMENT

Acute nephrolithiasis (kidney stone).

PLAN

1. Encourage the patient to push fluids to facilitate urination and help pass the stone.
2. Prescribe oxycodone 5 mg every 6 to 8 hours as needed for pain. The patient may continue to take Tylenol for breakthrough pain.
3. Provide a strainer for the patient to strain his urine and collect the stone when it passes.
4. Order a basic metabolic panel (BMP), urinalysis, and urine culture to evaluate for any signs of infection.
5. Schedule a follow-up appointment in 1 to 2 weeks to check on the patient's progress. If symptoms have not improved, discuss further treatment options, including lithotripsy or ureteroscopy.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient should contact the doctor if symptoms worsen or if there are any concerns.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Non-healing right foot ulcer.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Nicholas is a patient with a history of diabetes and diabetic neuropathy who presents today with a non-healing right foot ulcer. He has had the ulcer for approximately six weeks, which he first noticed after wearing a tight pair of shoes. The ulcer initially presented as a blister with stinging and burning sensations. Over time, the ulcer developed a foul smell, yellow drainage, and the skin around the wound turned black. The patient has been on antibiotics for six days, which initially improved symptoms but now reports cramping in his calf muscle and a red streak along the inside of his calf muscle. The patient also reports difficulty catching his breath and coughing in the last two days.

The patient's blood sugar has been trending in the 300-400 range in the last two weeks, with one spike at 500-600. His last hemoglobin A1c was 6.7.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient reports a history of diabetes and diabetic neuropathy.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient enjoys hiking and recently went on a hike with new diabetic shoes and inserts.

MEDICATIONS

Patient is currently on antibiotics for the foot ulcer.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Reports fever of 99.7 and chills.
Cardiovascular: No chest pain.
Respiratory: Reports difficulty catching breath and coughing.
Skin: Patient reports non-healing right foot ulcer with foul smell and yellow drainage.
Neurological: No reported issues.

VITALS

Slight fever.
Blood pressure: Not provided
Heart rate: Not provided

PHYSICAL EXAM

Foot exam: 2x2 cm necrotic wound on right heel with sloughing tissue, cellulitis, and erythemia. No bony exposure. Non-palpable dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses, but present via Doppler.
Vascular exam: Bilateral palpable femoral and popliteal pulses.

ASSESSMENT

1. Non-healing diabetic foot ulcer
2. Diabetes
3. Diabetic neuropathy

PLAN

1. Order a test to check blood supply for the wound.
2. Perform debridement in the office.
3. Obtain a culture and consider changing antibiotic therapy based on results.
4. Monitor redness and swelling in the calf.
5. Follow up in seven days.
6. Advise the patient to follow up with an endocrinologist for diabetes management.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Tick bite on right knee.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Patient reports a tick bite on the right knee, with erythema, edema, and a bull's-eye rash. The bite occurred over a week ago, and the patient has been experiencing a burning sensation and general malaise since then.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Hypertension: Controlled with lisinopril 20 mg daily.
Diabetes: Controlled with metformin 1000 mg twice daily.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Denies fever, chills.
Musculoskeletal: Reports arthritic pain, but no new joint pain.
Neurological: Reports headache since tick bite.

VITALS

Blood pressure: 122/70 mmHg
Heart rate: 67 bpm
Respiration: Not reported
Temperature: 98.4°F

PHYSICAL EXAM

Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm. No murmurs, gallops or rubs.
Respiratory: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally.
Musculoskeletal: Right knee with erythema, edema, and area of fluctuance over the right patella. Pain to palpation of the right anterior knee. Full range of motion of the right knee.
Skin: Bull's-eye rash over the right knee.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Suspected Lyme disease due to tick bite and bull's-eye rash.
- Medical Treatment: Start doxycycline 100 mg twice daily for 3 weeks.
- Diagnostic Testing: Order Lyme titer and Western blot to confirm diagnosis.

2. Hypertension: Well-controlled on lisinopril 20 mg daily.
- Continue current medication.
- Order lipid panel to assess cholesterol levels.

3. Diabetes: Blood sugars in the 120s, controlled with metformin 1000 mg twice daily.
- Continue current medication.
- Order hemoglobin A1c to assess long-term blood sugar control.
- Order basic metabolic panel to monitor kidney function.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up as needed.
